group_1.textRight: Amalily… Amaryllis?

group_1.textLeft: Ah… Amalily is fine.
Greek names are pretty hard to pronounce,@if you ask me!

group_1.textRight: Thank you, Ama…Amaryllis.
So you're Junia's handmaiden…
Do both of you share the same tutor?

group_1.textLeft: Yes, we study everything from Vergilius's@poetry to oration together…
I've been blessed with a wonderful opportunity@to learn more than I could ever know!

group_1.textRight: Hehe…I see.@So what did you want from me?

group_1.textLeft: As a matter of fact…

group_1.textRight: …And that's how you suddenly came into@my life.

group_1.textLeft: Hehe… I've been keen on you for a long time,@Lady Cornelia.

group_1.textRight: You're a total fangirl, huh?

group_1.textLeft: Yes, I've always admired her…@So intelligent, gentle, and kind…

group_1.textRight: I was surprised you knew my favorite food@even though we'd never met.

group_1.textLeft: I've been visiting your estate with Lady Junia@for quite some time!

group_1.textRight: …Junia was adopted by another family when@she was six years old.
She was taken in by my father's best friend…@and often still visits our estate.
So though you're sisters, your names differ@because you come from other families.

group_1.textLeft: That, that…@What do you mean by that?

group_1.textRight: In the time of Ancient Rome, sisters were called@by the same name.

group_1.textLeft: Yes, as it was when they lived together@in this villa.
Lady Junia was called Cornelia Minor…@or Cornelia the Younger.

group_1.textRight: …Seems complicated…?
So, like, Cornelia,
you believed Amaryllis's story just like that?

group_1.textLeft: Yes… That day, in the midst of a play starring@a popular actor, Master Paris,
she foresaw an enormous rainstorm would@suddenly unleash mayhem on the show,
and it turned out to be true…
From that point on, every now and then,
I'd drop by here and impose myself on you.

group_1.textRight: Sounds like you're great friends!

group_1.textLeft: Yes, and I had already studied Lady Cornelia's@preferences in advance.
In particular, when I brought this board game@to her,
she was especially curious about it…

group_1.textRight: Well, I'd been wanting to play for a while,@but I never had the chance…

group_1.textLeft: I enjoy Ludus myself, so we got along well.
But we didn't just spend our days playing@around, you know?

group_1.textRight: …It's an enormous undertaking to change@the future by yourself.
I suppose that's why you chose to ask for@Cornelia's assistance.

group_1.textLeft: H-how did you know?!@You're exactly right!

group_1.textRight: But why Cornelia?

group_1.textLeft: There's a deeper reason for that…
But before we get into it…@I have something I want to ask.

group_1.textRight: What's up?

group_1.textLeft: What Lady Nemu mentioned earlier…@about the disaster that befell us…
You mentioned it was known in the future@two thousand years from now, right?

group_1.textRight: Yes… An entire city was erased in a single night.@It's a tragedy rarely seen in history.
There's irony to the fact that Pompeii was@buried in ashes,
making it so that its streets and sights were@captured in a frozen moment of time.
The ruins of Pompeii stir the hearts of all those@who come to bear witness.

group_1.textLeft: It was hard to really grasp it from Amaryllis's@words alone,
but soon, this city truly will be gone…
Lady Nemu, Lady Nemu…
When Amaryllis was making her wish,
couldn't she have just asked Kyubey to make it@so the eruption never happened to begin with?

group_1.textRight: In this era, many people saw volcanic eruptions@not as natural phenomena,
but as the gods unleashing their wrath.

group_1.textLeft: Ah…

group_1.textRight: Besides, even if that wish were to be granted,
her days would be filled with the fear and@anxiety that another eruption would come.

group_1.textLeft: Yeah…@It's not so simple.
